page.title: 03Land Use In Bylaugh (2)
page.content: There is a part of this grid reference including a farm by a river and pits used for fishing and sailing, by permission of the owner occupiers. The farm is run for a butchery business. The abbatoir is on the other side of a road running through the farmland. The grass is used to feed sheep and cattle while waiting to be slaughtered as well as for rearing purposes. Some corn is grown which is made into cattle feed. The abbatoir has been equipped according to E.E.C. standards and many of the sheep passing through are sold in France. The remaining animals, purchased in mainly local markets, are sold through local retail outlets. Many families own a deep-freezer and buy their meat wholesale, as an example, in July 1985 an English lamb weighing 42 lbs cost 76 pence per lb.
